choices.text: Treacher Collins Syndrome

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl presents with a history of multiple craniofacial anomalies, including downward slanting eyes, and small jaw. The mother informs that the child had recurrent middle ear infections and has a history of hearing loss. Examination reveals a high-arched palate and respiratory difficulty due to upper airway obstruction. Imaging studies demonstrate hypoplasia of mandible with malocclusion and absence of the zygomatic arch. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the clinical features, radiological findings and the image given below?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Treacher Collins Syndrome

 

Option A.

 

Treacher Collins Syndrome is a rare genetic disorder affecting the development of the face.

 

  • Clinical features include Hypoplasia of Mandible and zygomatic arches, downward slanting eyes, cleft palate, respiratory difficulties, and hearing loss.
  • Other features include eyelid colobomas, eyelash abnormalities, and dental abnormalities.
  • Severity varies widely and treatment typically involves a multidisciplinary approach.
  • Associated congenital heart diseases are VSD, ASD, PDA

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Down Syndrome: Characterized by intellectual disability, distinct facial features (flat facial profile, slanted eyes, small ears), and other systemic manifestations. The specific craniofacial and radiological findings described do not typically align with Down Syndrome.

 

Option C. Seckel Syndrome: Known for primordial dwarfism, microcephaly, and a "bird-like" face, which does not specifically include the craniofacial anomalies or hearing issues described in the question.

 

Option D. Turner Syndrome: Affects females and involves a missing or partially missing X chromosome, leading to short stature, gonadal dysgenesis, and other physical abnormalities, but not typically the craniofacial anomalies described for TCS.

 

Ref: Nelson 21th Edition, Page No 7613

questions.text: A working mother brings her 3-year-old child to the pediatrician’s office for a routine check-up. On evaluation child is small for her age with a beak-like nose, narrow face, and widely spaced eyes as shown in the image. The mother reports that the child has difficulty feeding due to a small jaw and mouth, and has been slow to reach developmental milestones. The pediatrician diagnoses this as a case of Seckel syndrome. All of the following are features of Seckel syndrome, except?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Macrocephaly

 

Option B.

 

Seckel syndrome is characterized by intrauterine growth retardation, postnatal dwarfism, and a unique facial appearance except for macrocephaly, which is not associated with Seckel syndrome and thus is the correct answer.

 

Clinical features of Seckel syndrome include:

  • Microcephaly: a circumference that is below the 3rd percentile for their age and gender.
  • Intellectual disability:
  • Facial abnormalities: Features may include a beak-like nose, narrow face, and Micrognathia. The ears may be low set and rotated backward, and the eyes may be widely spaced and/or have a downward slant.
  • Skeletal abnormalities: Bones may be thin and/or abnormally shaped, and joints may be hypermobile.
  • Feeding difficulties
  • Other features:  heart defects, kidney abnormalities, and seizures.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A, C and D are the features of Seckel syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Seckel (SCKL) syndrome, sometimes called “bird-headed dwarfism,” is an autosomal recessive developmental disorder characterized by marked growth failure and mental deficiency, microcephaly, a hypoplastic face with a prominent nose, and low-set and/or malformed ears. Approximately 25% of patients have aplastic anemia or malignancies.

 

Note - There is broad genetic heterogeneity comprising at least 8 classifiable types: SCKL1, ATR mutation; SCKL2, RBBP8 mutation; SCKL3, maps to 14q21-q22; SCKL4, CENPJ mutation; SCKL5, CEP152 mutation; SCKL6, CEP63 mutation; SCKL7, NIN mutation; and SCKL8, ATRIP mutation.

 

Ref: Nelson 21th Edition, Page No 10133

questions.text: A mother brings her newborn to the hospital for a procedure, as shown in the image. The child has a history of hyperbilirubinemia. The infant is placed under a type of light as part of the treatment. Which mechanism is chiefly responsible for the reduction in the levels of serum bilirubin during the procedure depicted?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Structural isomerization

 

Option C: Structural isomerization

 

The procedure shown here is Phototherapy for neonatal Jaundice, the main mechanism seen in this case is Structural isomerization of the unconjugated bilirubin into the Lumirubin, which is a water-soluble compound excreted by the kidneys.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Photooxidation: This is a minor reaction, where, photoproducts are excreted in urine.

 

Option B. Photoisomerization: This term refers to the light-induced conversion of bilirubin to a different isomer, specifically converting the Z, Z-bilirubin to the more polar E,Z-bilirubin and E,E-bilirubin isomers. These isomers are more water-soluble and can be excreted without conjugation. It is is one of the mechanisms by which the phototherapy acts whereas the main mechanism is Structural isomerization.

 

Option D. Conjugation: Conjugation is a liver process where bilirubin is made water-soluble by adding a glucuronic acid molecule, allowing it to be excreted in bile. This is not the process used by phototherapy to reduce bilirubin; rather, it is the natural metabolic pathway that may be deficient in newborns, leading to hyperbilirubinemia.

 

Educational objective:

 

Phototherapy remains the mainstay of treating hyperbilirubinemia in neonates. It acts by converting insoluble bilirubin (unconjugated) into soluble isomers that can be excreted in urine and feces. The bilirubin molecule isomerizes to harmless forms under blue-green light (460-490 nm). Structural isomerization is mainly responsible for phototherapy induced decline in TSB.

 

Ref- OP Ghai 9th Edition Page No- 171.

questions.text: In a primary health center, a 26-year-old woman with an unknown date of her last menstrual period gives birth to a baby weighing 2100 grams. The healthcare team faces the challenge of assessing the newborn's maturity to ensure the provision of appropriate neonatal care. Given the absence of prenatal history for a newborn weighing 2100 grams at birth, which of the following sign should be evaluated by the healthcare team to determine the newborn's gestational maturity?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

Option D: 

 

The maturity of a newborn can be assessed using various physical and neuromuscular indicators, which are components of neonatal maturity assessment scales like the Ballard Score.

 

Explanation

 

Option A. Ear cartilage form and firmness: The development and firmness of the ear cartilage can indicate gestational maturity, with less mature neonates having softer, less well-defined cartilage.

 

Option B. Arm recoiling: This neuromuscular maturity indicator involves flexing the neonate's arm at the elbow and then releasing it. The speed and extent to which the arm returns to its flexed position can help assess neuromuscular development and, by extension, gestational age.

 

Option C. Plantar crease: The presence and depth of creases on the soles of the feet are used as a physical maturity indicator. More and deeper creases are generally associated with higher gestational age.

 

Educational Objective

 

Components of the Extended Ballard scoring

 

 

Ref- OP Ghai 9th Edition Page No- 138; Nelson 21st edition pg 3883-85

choices.text: Atropic Rhinitis
Nasal polyposis
Foreign body
Septal deviation.

questions.text: A 3-year-old, previously healthy child, is brought to the clinic by their mother due to a complaint of foul-smelling discharge from the left side of the nose. Examination reveals unilateral nasal obstruction and a foul-smelling discharge. Upon further examination, an object is seen in the nasal cavity, as shown in the image. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Foreign body

 

Option C:

 

  • Unilateral nasal obstruction with foul-smelling discharge is the classic presentation of retained foreign body in the nose in young children.
  • TH child may present with features of bleeding per nose.
  • The examination with nasal speculum and removal by endoscope is advised.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Atrophic Rhinitis: This is a chronic condition characterized by atrophy of the nasal mucosa and is uncommon in young children.

 

Option B. Nasal Polyposis: Nasal polyps are typically bilateral and not usually associated with a foul smell. They are also rare in this age group.

 

Option D. Septal Deviation: This structural issue typically does not cause a foul-smelling discharge and is usually not diagnosed in such young children unless associated with trauma or congenital malformation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The key indicators of a nasal foreign body include unilateral nasal obstruction, foul-smelling discharge, and the visualization of an object in the nasal cavity. Prompt recognition and removal of the foreign body are essential to prevent complications such as infection and further obstruction.

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition page no 8739-8744

choices.text: Acute laryngitis
Acute tonsillitis
Acute epiglottitis
Acute pharyngitis

questions.text: A mother brings her 6-year-old child presenting with complaints of high fever, severe sore throat, difficulty swallowing, drooling, and inspiratory stridor. On examination, the child appears anxious, has a muffled voice, and the following appearance. Based on these findings given, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Acute epiglottitis

 

Option C:

 

The most likely diagnosis in this case is Acute epiglottitis. The presence of high fever, severe sore throat, difficulty swallowing, drooling, and inspiratory stridor, along with an anxious appearance, muffled voice, and a cherry-red epiglottis in the image are all consistent with acute epiglottitis.

 

  • Acute epiglottitis is a serious medical emergency that requires immediate treatment to prevent airway obstruction and respiratory failure.
  • Treatment of acute epiglottitis involves immediate airway management, such as intubation or tracheostomy, to maintain airway patency.
  • Antibiotics are also administered to treat the underlying bacterial infection causing the epiglottitis.
  • It is important to note that the use of oral examination or throat swab to diagnose acute epiglottitis should be avoided due to the risk of airway obstruction due to LARYNGOSPASM.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Acute laryngitis presents with hoarseness, cough, and mild throat pain, but lacks the characteristic symptoms and physical findings seen in acute epiglottitis.

 

Option B. Acute tonsillitis presents with sore throat, fever, and enlarged tonsils, but lacks the inspiratory stridor and cherry-red epiglottis.

 

Option D. Acute pharyngitis presents with sore throat, fever, and enlarged lymph nodes, but lacks the drooling, inspiratory stridor, and cherry-red epiglottis seen in acute epiglottitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute epiglottitis, a potentially life-threatening condition characterized by rapid onset of high fever, severe sore throat, difficulty swallowing, drooling, inspiratory stridor, anxious appearance, and the presence of a "thumb sign" on lateral neck X-rays. Prompt recognition and management are essential to prevent airway compromise and respiratory distress.

 

Ref: Nelson 20th Edition page 8702

questions.text:
A 2-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his mother, who is concerned about his failure to thrive and developmental delays. Karyotyping is performed, the result is shown below. What is the most common cardiac condition seen in this child?
 

 

What is the most common cardiac condition seen in this child?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Ventricular Septal Defect

 

Option B:

 

Based on the image and clinical description provided, the karyotype shows an abnormal characteristic of Trisomy 18, also known as Edwards syndrome. This is evidenced by the presence of three copies of chromosome 18. Children with Trisomy 18 often present with a range of clinical features, including developmental delays, failure to thrive, and distinctive craniofacial and hand features.

 

Ventricular septal defect (VSD) is the most common cardiac anomaly associated with Trisomy 18. VSD is a hole in the wall separating the two lower chambers of the heart, which allows oxygen-rich blood to mix with oxygen-poor blood, potentially causing heart failure and other complications.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Atrial Septal Defect - While ASDs can occur in Trisomy 18, they are not as common as VSDs.

 

Option C. Mitral Valve Prolapse - This is not commonly associated with Trisomy 18.

 

Option D. Mitral Stenosis - This condition, characterized by the narrowing of the mitral valve, is also not commonly associated with Trisomy 18.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Trisomy 18 (Edward Syndrome) - The 2nd most common autosomal trisomy.

 

Clinical features include:

 

  • Rocker bottom feet

  • Overlapping fingers

  • Clenched fist

  • Short sternum

  • Hypoplastic nails

  • Hypoplastic nasal alae

  • IUGR

  • Intellectual disability

  • Microcephaly

  • Hypertonia

  • Prominent occiput

  • Micrognathia

  • Limited hip abduction

  • Cleft lip / palate

 

Most common cardiac defects:

 

  • Ventricular septal defect (VSD)

  • Atrial septal defect (ASD)

  • PDA

 

Most common cause of death: Central apnea

 

Prenatal screen lab findings:

 

  • Low alpha feto protein

  • Low unconjugated estriol

  • Low beta hCG

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition, Chapter 98, Page No. 3024

choices.text: Watersons shunt: PA is joined to ascending aorta
Potts shunt: PA is joined to descending aorta
Modified Blalock-Taussig Shunt: Subclavian artery is joined to pulmonary artery
Potts shunt: PA is joined to ascending aorta.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child with a history of cyanotic heart disease is brought to the pediatric surgery outpatient department by their mother. The pediatric surgeon conducts a thorough examination and then engages in a teaching moment with the residents, discussing the various shunt surgeries available for managing such conditions. The surgeon presents several options and asks the residents to identify which statement about shunt surgeries is incorrect, emphasizing the need for precision in understanding and choosing the appropriate surgical intervention.
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Potts shunt: PA is joined to ascending aorta

 

Option D:

 

Potts shunt actually involves the anastomosis between the pulmonary artery and the descending aorta, not the ascending aorta. This shunt is used to increase pulmonary blood flow in certain types of congenital heart defects. By connecting the left pulmonary artery to the descending aorta, blood flow to the lungs is increased, which can improve oxygenation in patients with cyanotic heart disease.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Watersons shunt: This is accurate as it describes connecting the right pulmonary artery to the ascending aorta, a method used to augment pulmonary blood flow in specific heart conditions.

 

Option B. Potts shunt: This correctly identifies the traditional Potts shunt connection between the left pulmonary artery and the descending aorta.

 

Option C. Modified Blalock-Taussig Shunt: This accurately describes the connection between the subclavian artery and the pulmonary artery, a common procedure to increase pulmonary blood flow in cyanotic heart diseases.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Shunt surgeries are used in the palliative care in case of TOF (Tetralogy of Fallot). These surgeries include:

 

  1. Waterstons shunt: PA is joined to ascending aorta

  2. Potts shunt: PA is joined to descending aorta

  3. Modified Blalock-Taussig Shunt: Subclavian artery is joined to pulmonary artery

 

Ref: Nelson 21st edition page 9234

choices.text: Give the child a 2-week trial of stimulant medication
Obtain further information from the parents and teachers
Reassure the child’s mother that this behavior is age appropriate
Send the child for psychological assessment

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the outpatient pediatric department by his mother, who expresses concerns that her son might have Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD). She describes him as being extremely restless at home, having a persistent inability to focus on tasks, and frequently misplacing his belongings. Despite these concerns, the child appears cooperative during the visit and his physical examination does not reveal any abnormalities. The mother is eager for advice on how to manage her son's symptoms and improve his ability to concentrate and remain organized. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Obtain further information from the parents and teachers.

 

Option B:


When ADHD is suspected, it is critical to gather comprehensive information from multiple sources, including parents, teachers, and other caregivers, to understand the child's behavior in different settings. ADHD symptoms must be present in more than one setting (e.g., both at home and school) to meet diagnostic criteria. This information can be collected using standardized rating scales and questionnaires that assess the child's behavior, attention span, and impulsivity across various environments. This approach helps to ensure a thorough evaluation and accurate diagnosis before considering treatment options.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Give the child a 2-week trial of stimulant medication - Starting medication without a thorough assessment and definitive diagnosis is inappropriate. Stimulant medications are a mainstay in the treatment of ADHD but should only be considered after a comprehensive evaluation confirms the diagnosis.

 

Option C. Reassure the child’s mother that this behavior is age appropriate - While some level of inattention and restlessness can be normal for children, the mother's concerns and the description of the child's behavior warrant a thorough evaluation to rule out ADHD or other disorders.

 

Option D. Send the child for psychological assessment - While a psychological assessment may be part of the evaluation process for ADHD, the initial step should involve gathering detailed information from those who observe the child in various settings. If the initial information supports the possibility of ADHD, a more in-depth psychological assessment might then be warranted.

 

Educational Objective:


The initial approach to evaluate a child suspected of having ADHD - Comprehensive evaluation including obtaining a detailed information from parents and teachers, is essential before considering a diagnosis of ADHD and discussing treatment options. This ensures that any intervention is based on a thorough understanding of the child's behaviors across different environments.

 

Ref: O P Ghai 9th Edition Page No- 56-59

choices.text: Respiratory Distress syndrome.
Grade IV Intraventricular hemorrhage
Apnea of prematurity
Retinopathy of prematurity stage 1

questions.text: An infant girl is born prematurely at 29 weeks of gestation due to an incompetent cervix and undergoes spontaneous vaginal delivery. Given the risks associated with prematurity, the neonate is closely monitored and admitted to the neonatal intensive care unit (NICU). Which aspect of her clinical course in the NICU is most likely to correlate with her long-term clinical outcome five years in the future?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Grade IV Intraventricular hemorrhage.

 

Option B:

 

Intraventricular hemorrhage is a complication in preterm infants.

 

It is associated with seizures, hydrocephalus, and periventricular leukomalacia.

 

A grade IV bleed involves the brain parenchyma, putting this child at higher risk for neurodevelopmental handicap.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Respiratory Distress Syndrome (RDS):

 

  • Description: RDS is a common respiratory complication in preterm infants due to immature lungs, leading to difficulty breathing.
  • Significance: While RDS can have immediate implications, its severity may not always be the strongest predictor of long-term outcomes.

 

Option C. Apnea of Prematurity:

 

  • Description: Apnea of prematurity is a temporary cessation of breathing for >20 seconds in preterm infants due to immature respiratory centers in the brain.
  • Significance: While apnea is significant in the neonatal period, its correlation with long-term outcomes may not be as direct as with certain neurological complications.

 

Option D. Retinopathy of Prematurity (ROP) Stage 1:

 

  • Description: ROP is an eye disorder in preterm infants, and Stage 1 is the least severe form, involving abnormal blood vessel growth in the retina.
  • Significance: ROP, especially in its early stages, may not be as strongly correlated with long-term neurodevelopmental outcomes compared to severe intraventricular hemorrhage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Grade IV IVH is the most severe form of bleeding into the brain's ventricles in preterm infants.
  • Significance: Severe IVH is associated with an increased risk of long-term neurodevelopmental issues, making it a potential predictor of clinical outcomes.

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition page number 3934

choices.text: 20 mL/hr
30 mL/hr
40 mL/hr
50 mL/hr

questions.text: A mother brings her newborn to the clinic, concerned about the baby's head, which appears enlarged and features visible veins. The physician, after evaluating the newborn, determines that the baby's condition is due to a disruption in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) flow, leading to accumulation. While discussing the diagnosis and implications with the family, the mother's sister inquires about normal CSF production in a child. What is the normal rate of CSF production in a child?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 20 mL/hr

 

Explanation:

 

The normal rate of CSF production in a child is approximately 20 mL/hr. CSF is produced by the choroid plexuses located in the ventricles of the brain and the rate remains relatively constant. This production leads to a total turnover of CSF about three to four times per day in both children and adults.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The normal production of CSF in an infant is 20 mL/hr.

 

Overproduction or under excretion, resulting from an obstruction in the CSF flow pathway will result in Hydrocephalus.

 

Ref: OP Ghai 9th Edition, Page No-578.

questions.text: A 15-year-old male visits the pediatric department with symptoms of weight gain, fatigue, increased sensitivity to cold, dry skin, and facial puffiness, leading to a diagnosis of hypothyroidism. During the consultation, the child exhibits difficulties in understanding, prompting an ENT consultation. On Pure Tone Audiometry the following Graph is obtained and there was a mutation in Cl-Iodine transporter.  Based on these findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Pendred Syndrome

 

Option D:

 

Pendred Syndrome is characterized by sensorineural hearing loss, which could explain the child's difficulties in understanding, and thyroid dysfunction, which aligns with the symptoms of hypothyroidism. The presence of a mutation in the Cl-Iodine transporter is also consistent with Pendred Syndrome, as this genetic alteration affects iodine transport in the thyroid and inner ear, leading to goiter and hearing loss.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Hashimoto's thyroiditis: An autoimmune disorder leading to hypothyroidism, but not typically associated with hearing loss or mutations in the Cl-Iodine transporter.

 

Option B. Thyroid dyshormonogenesis: Refers to a group of disorders causing hypothyroidism due to enzymatic defects in thyroid hormone synthesis, but not usually linked to hearing loss.

 

Option D. Graves' disease: An autoimmune disorder characterized by hyperthyroidism, not hypothyroidism, and not associated with hearing loss.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pendred Syndrome is due to mutation in the PDS gene on 7th chromosome which codes for Chloride/Iodide transporter. The features of Pendred syndrome are Sensory Neural Hearing Loss (SNHL) along with goitre and hypothyroidism.

 

Ref; Nelson 21st Edition, Chapter 581 Page No- 11398-11423

questions.text: A 15-year-old male is brought to the pediatric department by his parents, who are concerned about his vision problems. Upon further evaluation, it is revealed that the child has a history of multiple health issues, including a diagnosis of retinitis pigmentosa in early childhood, which has led to progressive vision loss. Based on the information provided, which of the following features is not associated with the syndrome affecting this child?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Syndactyly.

 

Option A:

 

The child's presentation, including vision loss due to retinitis pigmentosa, obesity, and potential hypogonadism, suggests a diagnosis consistent with Bardet-Biedl syndrome, a genetic condition. Rod-cone dystrophy, another term for retinitis pigmentosa, is a defining feature of this syndrome. However, syndactyly, or the fusion of fingers or toes, is not a common feature associated with Bardet-Biedl syndrome, making it the correct choice for the feature not seen in this syndrome.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Obesity: Obesity is a common feature in Bardet-Biedl syndrome, often developing in early childhood.

 

Option C. Rod-cone dystrophy: This term refers to retinitis pigmentosa, a hallmark of Bardet-Biedl syndrome, characterized by progressive vision loss starting in childhood.

 

Option D. Hypogonadism: Hypogonadism, which can manifest as a delay in or absence of puberty, is another potential feature of Bardet-Biedl syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Laurence Moon syndrome.

 

  • Retinitis pigmentosa (Rod- cone dystrophy),
  • Obesity,
  • Postaxial polydactyly,
  • Spastic paresis,
  • Learning disabilities and
  • Hypogonadism in males.

 

Ref; Nelson 20th Edition Page No – 310.

questions.text: A Medical Officer in a Regional healthcare center is addressing concerns of a mother who is worried about her milk supply being inadequate for her infant's needs. The MO assures her that breast milk composition typically provides all necessary nutrients in the right amounts. To demonstrate this point, she quizzes the interns present, about the sodium content of breast milk. What is the sodium content in breast milk measured in mEq/L?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 7 mEq/L

 

Explanation:

 

Breast milk has a relatively low sodium content compared to other fluids, which is appropriate for the kidney's filtering capacity of an infant. On average, breast milk contains 7 mEq/L of sodium, which meets the infant's nutritional requirements without overloading their renal system.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition, Page No 1796

questions.text: A 32-year-old working mother in a multinational company brings her 3-month-old infant to your clinic for a routine pediatric visit. After returning to work postpartum, she expresses a desire to transition her baby from breast milk to cow's milk due to her busy schedule. She inquires about the nutritional differences between human milk and cow's milk, specifically asking which component is present in higher quantities in human milk compared to cow's milk. Which of the following is the correct response?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lactose

 

Option A:

 

Human milk contains higher levels of lactose compared to cow's milk. Lactose is not just a source of energy; it also aids in the absorption of essential minerals like calcium and magnesium and supports the growth of beneficial gut bacteria, which is crucial for the infant's developing immune system and digestive health.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Calcium: Cow's milk actually contains higher levels of calcium than human milk. However, the bioavailability of calcium in human milk is better, meaning infants can absorb it more efficiently.

 

Option C. Protein: Cow's milk contains a higher concentration of total protein than human milk. The protein composition in cow's milk is also different, which can be harder for infants to digest and may lead to an increased risk of allergic reactions.

 

Option D. Fat: While the total fat content may be similar in both human and cow's milk, the composition of fat in human milk is uniquely suited to the human infant's needs, including essential fatty acids crucial for brain development that are not present in cow's milk in the same ratios.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: OP Ghai 9th Page No- 145.

choices.text: First Day of Admission
20th Day of Admission

questions.text: A pediatrician is strategizing the nutritional rehabilitation plan for a child with Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM). Given the complexities associated with SAM, careful consideration is given to the timing of iron supplementation to avoid exacerbating the condition. At what point in the treatment of SAM is iron supplementation deemed appropriate?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rehabilitation Phase

 

Option B:

 

Iron supplementation is introduced during the Rehabilitation Phase of SAM treatment to avoid potential adverse effects such as oxidative stress and increased susceptibility to infections that can occur if given during the initial, more critical Stabilization Phase.

 

The general treatment involves ten steps in two phases:

 

  • The initial stabilization phase focuses on restoring homeostasis and treating medical complications and usually takes 2-7 days of inpatient treatment.
  • The rehabilitation phase focuses on rebuilding wasted tissues and may take several week

 

The time frame for Management of Severe Malnutrition in 10 steps

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: In the Stabilization Phase, the focus is on managing acute complications and stabilizing the child's condition; iron could exacerbate infections.

 

Option C & Option D: Specifying exact days (First Day or 20th Day) is less relevant than understanding the phase of treatment. Iron is not typically started based on the day of admission but rather the child's clinical progress and phase of treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Iron in SAM is not given in the stabilization phase as it can lead to free radical generation and bacterial fermentation. The appropriate timing for iron supplementation in SAM treatment, is Rehabilitation Phase.

 

Ref: Op Ghai 9th Edition, Page No- 93.

questions.text: In managing a 13-month with SAM who weighs 7 kg, a medical officer prepares to administer Vitamin A as part of the comprehensive treatment plan. What is the correct dosage of Vitamin A for this infant?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 100,000 IU

 

Explanation:

 

Vitamin A dose

 

<6 months: 50,000 IU

 

6-12 months: 1 lakh IU

 

>12 months: 2 Lakh IU

 

If the baby is >12 months & <8kg: 1 lakh IU

 

Educational Objective:

 

Management of SAM - Micronutrients supplementation

 

  • Use up to twice the recommended daily allowance of various vitamins and minerals

  • On day 1, give vitamin A orally (if age >1 yr give 2 lakh IU; age 6-12 mo give 1 lakh IU; age 0-5 mo give 50,000 IU)

  • Folic acid 1 mg/ day (give 5 mg on day 1)

  • Zinc 2 mg/kg/ day

  • Copper 0.2-0.3 mg/kg/day

  • Iron 3 mg/ kg/ day, once child starts gaining weight; after the stabilization phase

 

Ref: Op Ghai 9th Edition, Page No- 93.

questions.text: A concerned mother presents to the pediatric clinic with her child, who has experienced 7 episodes of loose stools from morning till evening. Upon examination, the pediatrician notes mild dehydration in the child. Considering the clinical presentation and the need for rehydration, which of the following is the most appropriate initial fluid choice for managing diarrhea in this infant?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) ORS

 

Option C:

 

The initial fluid of choice for diarrhea in an infant is ORS. Oral Rehydration Solution (ORS) is the recommended first-line treatment for rehydration in infants and children with mild to moderate dehydration due to diarrhea. ORS is specifically formulated to contain the ideal balance of salts and sugars to facilitate water absorption in the intestines, effectively replacing lost fluids and electrolytes. Its composition aligns with the World Health Organization (WHO) guidelines for rehydration, making it highly effective in preventing and treating dehydration from diarrhea in children.

 

The cornerstone of acute diarrhea management is rehydration by using oral rehydration solutions (ORS).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Salt Water: While rehydration requires salt, salt water alone is not recommended due to its high sodium concentration, which can worsen dehydration and lead to hypernatremia.

 

Option B. Sugar Water: Sugar water can provide some energy but lacks the necessary electrolytes needed to correct the electrolyte imbalances caused by diarrhea. It is not sufficient for rehydration purposes.

 

Option D. Normal Saline: Normal Saline is an intravenous solution that can be used in more severe cases of dehydration or when oral rehydration is not possible. However, for mild dehydration and when oral intake is feasible, ORS is preferred due to its ease of use and effectiveness in promoting intestinal water and electrolyte absorption.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oral Rehydration Solution (ORS) is the recommended first-line treatment for rehydration in infants and children with mild to moderate dehydration due to diarrhea. ORS is specifically formulated to contain the ideal balance of salts and sugars to facilitate water absorption in the intestine.

 

Ref: OP Ghai 9th Edition, Page No-289.

questions.text: During a review session with interns, you decide to test their knowledge on vaccine strains with a matching exercise. Match the following vaccines with their respective strains:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A3 B4 C1 D2

Explanation:

 

Option A. (OPV) is matched with 3 (Sabin), which refers to the oral polio vaccine developed by Albert Sabin.

Option B: (IPV) is matched with 4 (Salk), indicating the inactivated polio vaccine developed by Jonas Salk.

Option C. (Measles) is matched with 1 (Edmonston-Zagreb), a strain used in the measles vaccine.

Option D. (Mumps) is matched with 2 (Jeryl Lynn), a strain used in the mumps vaccine.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition page 741

choices.text: The child is at risk of developing gallstones
Iron supplements are indicated in the management of the disease
The child may require blood transfusions

questions.text: A mother brings her 6-year-old child to a local clinic with concerns about the child's noticeably distended abdomen and a history of recurrent infections. Upon physical examination, the child exhibits notable pallor and splenomegaly. The physical examination findings of the child revealed the following image. Additionally, an X-ray of the skull shows abnormal bone structure with a "crew cut" appearance, indicative of bone marrow expansion. A peripheral blood smear reveals microcytic hypochromic red blood cells and target cells. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Iron supplements are indicated in the management of the disease.

 

Option C:

 

Iron supplements may actually exacerbate the symptoms of beta-thalassemia as patients with the disease are at risk for iron overload.

 

Beta-thalassemia is a genetic disorder that affects the production of beta-globin chains and is characterized by microcytic hypochromic RBCs and target cells. Patients with the disease may require blood transfusions and are at risk for complications such as splenomegaly, recurrent infections, and gallstones.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The child may have beta-thalassemia: True, the clinical findings of facial bone deformities, splenomegaly, and a blood smear showing microcytic hypochromic RBCs with target cells are consistent with beta-thalassemia.

 

Option B. The child is at risk of developing gallstones: True, chronic hemolysis associated with beta-thalassemia increases the risk of bilirubinate gallstones.

 

Option D. The child may require blood transfusions: True, patients with beta-thalassemia major often require regular blood transfusions to manage severe anemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Beta-thalassemia can present with facial bone deformities, splenomegaly, and specific blood smear findings. Management often involves regular blood transfusions, while iron supplementation is not typically indicated due to the risk of iron overload.

 

Ref; OP Ghai 9th Edition Page No- 339-342

questions.text: A 6-year-old child from Africa is brought by his parents for medical consultation, presenting with pronounced jaw swelling and ulceration as evident in the provided image. The child also exhibits difficulty breathing due to partial airway obstruction. A biopsy is performed, and histopathological analysis confirms a diagnosis of B-cell Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma (NHL). Based on the clinical presentation and biopsy findings, what is the most likely diagnosis, and which chromosomal translocation is associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Burkitt’s lymphoma t (8;14)

 

Option D:

 

Burkitt’s lymphoma

  • Caused by the deregulation of the MYC gene on chromosome
  • EBV infection predisposes to c-myc translocation t(8;14)

 

Clinical features; BL is a rapidly growing tumor.

  • The endemic (African) form usually presents as a jaw or facial bone, loosening of teeth, tumor that spreads to extra nodal sites including the mesentery, ovary, testis, kidney, breast, and especially to the bone marrow and meninges

 

INVESTIGATION

  • CBC
  • RFTs and Serum electrolytes, uric acid, creatinine, calcium, phosphorus, Biopsy - histological Dx

 

Histology —

  • Cytologically, BL cells resemble the small non-cleaved cells within normal germinal centers
  • A "starry sky" pattern is usually present
     

Management

  • General management Prevent tumour lysis SDM
  • Rehydrate the patient
  • Allopurinol and Rasburicase.
  • Specific management; Cyclophosphamide, Vincristine, Prednisolone (CHOP)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Burkitt’s lymphoma, especially the classic presentation is of jaw swelling in African children, and its associated with the chromosomal translocation t(8;14).

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition page number 6904

choices.text: Ultrasound of abdomen
Use of enuresis alarm

questions.text: A mother brings her 8-year-old boy with complaints of bedwetting. On asking history, she informs that he does about 3 to 4 times per week. On further evaluation, he has a normal urine stream, daytime urine continence, and no history of UTIs. His physical examination is normal. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Use of enuresis alarm

 

Option C:

 

The presentation of bedwetting (nocturnal enuresis) in an otherwise healthy child with normal daytime urinary continence and no history of urinary tract infections (UTIs) suggests primary nocturnal enuresis.

 

The first-line treatment for primary nocturnal enuresis is behavioral therapy, and the use of an enuresis alarm is the most appropriate next step in management. Enuresis alarms work by detecting urine and waking the child up when they begin to wet the bed, eventually helping to condition them to wake up before fully emptying their bladder.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Ultrasound of abdomen: Routine ultrasound of the abdomen is not indicated in the initial evaluation of primary nocturnal enuresis without other concerning symptoms or signs.

 

Option B. Reassurance: While reassurance is an important aspect of management, it alone may not be sufficient for addressing primary nocturnal enuresis.

 

Option D. Desmopressin acetate: Desmopressin acetate, a synthetic form of antidiuretic hormone (ADH), is another treatment option for primary nocturnal enuresis, particularly for children who do not respond to behavioral interventions such as enuresis alarms or who need additional help in achieving dry nights. However, it is typically reserved for cases where behavioral therapy has failed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nocturnal enuresis occurs in 15% of 5-year-olds with a resolution rate of 15% per year. Males are more frequently affected, and family history is common. Initial evaluation includes a history of wetting pattern, prior UTI, and developmental, social, and emotional history.

 

  • The enuresis alarm has a success rate of 70% to 90% and requires parental support.
  • Pharmacologic interventions include nighttime doses of imipramine or oral desmopressin acetate.
  • Following use of desmopressin acetate, fluid intake is restricted to avoid hyponatremia.
  • Pharmacologic treatment usually is reserved for special occasions.

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition, Chapter 558 Page No- From 11044.

questions.text: A mother brings her child with features of multiple teeth and a soft skull. On examination, the child is able to touch his both shoulder joints. On further evaluation, he is found to have defective membranous ossification. The images of his findings are given below. What is your diagnosis based on the features?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Cleidocranial dysostosis

 

Option C:

 

The clinical features is suggestive of Cleidocranial dysostosis. The key features of this condition include:

 

  • Clavicles may be underdeveloped or absent. Most common defect is the loss of lateral 1/3rd clavicle > loss of middle third clavicle. Due to absence of clavicle shoulders look droopy, chest appears narrow & when B/L loss occurs both shoulders can touch each other in front of the chest.
  • Delayed closure of fontanelles and cranial sutures, leading to a soft skull.
     
  • Supernumerary teeth and dental abnormalities. High arched palate is also seen.
     
  • Defective ossification, particularly affecting membranous bones.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Chondro-osteodystrophy: This term is not commonly used in clinical practice and does not specifically match the features described in the scenario.

 

Option B: Shoulder Dislocation: While the ability to touch the shoulder joints together might suggest joint laxity, the systemic features of multiple teeth and a soft skull are not consistent with a simple shoulder dislocation.

 

Option D: Osteogenesis Imperfecta: This condition is primarily characterized by brittle bones that fracture easily, which is not described in the provided scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cleidocranial dysostosis/ cleidocranial dysplasia, is a rare genetic (autosomal dominant) associated with mutations in the RUNX2 gene, which plays a critical role in bone development and ossification.

 

Ref- Nelson 21st EDITION page 14389

questions.text: A 9-month-old child presents with recurrent infections, fatigue, and bleeding episodes. The attending physician notes anemia, leukopenia, and thrombocytopenia on a complete blood count. Upon examination, the child exhibits features suggestive of Mucopolysaccharidoses. Considering the clinical presentation and laboratory findings, the physician considers diseases for which enzyme replacement therapy (ERT) is not enough to treat the condition as a single aid. Which of the following diseases cannot be treated with enzyme replacement therapy alone?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hunters disease

 

Option C:

 

Hunters disease (Mucopolysaccharidosis type II) cannot be effectively managed with enzyme replacement therapy (ERT) alone. This limitation arises because the currently available enzyme formulations do not cross the blood-brain barrier, rendering them insufficient for addressing the neurological aspects of the disease. This necessitates additional therapeutic approaches for comprehensive management.

 

All of the mucopolysaccharidoses are Autosomal Recessive in nature, whereas Hunters disease has X-Linked Recessive with a CAG trinucleotide repeat, CORNEAL CLOUDING IS NOT SEEN IN HUNTER DISEASE

 

Common Presentations of Mucopolysaccharidoses:

 

  • Mental retardation

  • Developmental delay

  • Severe behavioral problems

  • Corneal clouding

  • Coarse facial features

  • Short stature, short trunk

  • Skeletal irregularities

  • Hepatosplenomegaly

  • Cardiac disease

  • Retinal degeneration

  • Hair loss or Hirsutism

  • Coarse facial features (flat nasal bridge, thick lips and large tongue, Prominent forehead)

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Gaucher's disease: Gaucher's disease is treatable with enzyme replacement therapy using imiglucerase, velaglucerase alfa, or taliglucerase alfa, which are recombinant forms of the deficient enzyme glucocerebrosidase.

 

Option B. Hurlers disease: Although Hurler's disease also requires more than ERT due to its severe and systemic nature, if addressing specifically enzyme replacement efficacy, it can still be part of the treatment protocol alongside other interventions like hematopoietic stem cell transplantation.

 

Option D. Fabrys disease: Fabrys disease can be treated with enzyme replacement therapy using agalsidase beta or agalsidase alfa.

 

Educational Objective:

Hunter's disease, a form of Mucopolysaccharidosis, requires treatment approaches beyond enzyme replacement therapy due to its neurological involvement, which ERT alone cannot address.

Enzyme replacement therapy is available for Gauchers disease, Hurlers disease, Fabrys disease and Pompes disease.

 

Ref: Nelson 21st edition, Chapter 107 Page No 3551

questions.text: A woman who is 18 weeks pregnant attends the antenatal clinic with fever, chills and malaise. She has just returned from working in East Africa. A peripheral blood film is examined, and a diagnosis of malaria is made. The organism identified is Plasmodium vivax. What is the treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Chloroquine

  • Treat malaria in pregnancy as an emergency.
  • Intravenous artesunate is the treatment of choice for severe falciparum malaria.
  • Use intravenous quinine if artesunate is not available.
  • Use quinine and clindamycin to treat uncomplicated P. falciparum (or mixed, such as P. falciparum and P. vivax).
  • Use chloroquine to treat P. vivax, P. ovale or P. malariae.
  • Primaquine should not be used in pregnancy. (It can cause hemolysis in the fetus)
  • Do not persist with oral therapy if vomiting is persistent.
  • Treat the fever with antipyretics.
  • Screen women with malaria for anaemia and treat appropriately.

Ref: https://www.rcog.org.uk/globalassets/documents/guidelines/gtg_54b.pdf

questions.text: A 23-year G2 is detected to have asymptomatic bacteriuria at 16 weeks. If left untreated, what is her risk of developing symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 25%

 

Explanation

 

  • If asymptomatic bacteriuria (ASB) is not treated, approximately 25 percent of affected women will develop symptomatic infection during pregnancy.
  • Eradication of bacteriuria with antimicrobial agents prevents most of these.
  • The American Academy of Pediatrics and the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (2017), as well as the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force (2019), recommend screening for bacteriuria at the first prenatal visit

 

Ref: Page no 2589, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Improve anemia, pre-operatively
Shrink the size of the fibroid pre-operatively
Small submucosal fibroid in an infertile woman

questions.text: Which is not an indication for medical management of fibroid uterus?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Small submucosal fibroid in an infertile woman

Explanation:

The indications of medical management in fibroid uterus is

  • Patients not desirous of fertility but wanting uterine preservation
  • Small symptomatic fibroids
  • Improving anemia
  • Peri-menopausal
  • Pre-op to shrink the size of the fibroid

In an infertile woman, any submucosal fibroid, even if small has to be removed

Educational Objective:

Remember if a woman is infertile; remove

  • Submucosal fibroids
  • Intramural fibroids
    • > 5 cm
    • Distorting the endometrial cavity

 

Ref: Page no 527, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 7th edition

choices.text: Extra-amniotic instillation of ethacridine
Concentrated oxytocin

questions.text: The preferred method for an induced abortion at 10 weeks is:
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Vacuum aspiration

Explanation

Other Options: 

  • Option A: Mifepritone + Misoprostol is preferred till 9 weeks but efficacy reduces after 7 weeks
  • Option C: Extra amniotic instillation of ethacridine lactate: This is done very rarely now in 2nd trimester abortions
  • Option D: Concentrated oxytocin: This is a rare approach, sometimes tried for 2nd trimester abortions

Educational Objective: 

Ref: Page no 164, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 9th edition

choices.text: Cervarix
Cervavac
Gardasil
Gardasil 9

questions.text: A P4L4, 43-year-old woman presents to OPD with post coital bleeding. On cervical biopsy, she is found to have CIN III. You counsel her about her treatment and also guide her for preventive strategy for her 2 daughters (17 years, 12-year-old) with HPV vaccine. Which of the following is the indigenous cervical cancer vaccine soon to be available in India by serum institute of India:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Cervavac
 

Ref: https://isccp.in/cervavac-the-new-buzz/
 

The National Cancer Institute of the US National Institute of Health (NIH) reports that three vaccines are currently being offered in numerous nations all over the world to prevent infection with the disease-causing HPV. These include Cervarix, Gardasil, and Gardasil 9.
 

The vaccines Cervarix is bivalent, Gardasil 9 is nonavalent, and Gardasil is quadrivalent. This translates to four, nine, and two HPV strains in Gardasil, Gardasil 9, and Cervarix, respectively.
 

HPV types 6, 11, 16, and 18 are prevented by Gardasil, while HPV types 16 and 18 are prevented by Cervarix.
Infection with HPV types 6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52, and 58 is prevented with Gardasil 9.
 

Cervavac: Tetravalent or quadrivalent L1 virus-like particles (VLPs) of serotypes 6, 11, 16, and 18 are part of the serum institute of India (SII)’s HPV vaccination.

questions.text: As per the WHO, abortion is defined as pregnancy loss or termination before:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 20 weeks

 

  • The WHO and the CDC define abortion as pregnancy loss or termination before 20 weeks or with a fetus < 500g

 

Ref: Williams Obstetrics 25th edition; page no 346

questions.text:
The Chorionicity of a Dizygotic pregnancy?

 

  1. Monochorionic Monoamniotic
  2. Monochorionic Diamniotic
  3. Monoamniotic Dichorionic
  4. Dichorionic Diamniotic
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Only 4.

 

Types of twins:

 

  • Dizygotic twins are formed when 2 ova are fertilized by 2 sperm, so they are always Dichorionic Diamniotic
  • Monozygotic (1 ova + 1 sperm) – undergoes division & Dizygotic (2 ova + 2 sperm)
  • Depending on when they divide, different types of twins are formed
    • First 3 days – Dichorionic Diamniotic
    • 4th day – 7th day – Monochorionic Diamniotic
    • 8th – 12th day – Monochorionic Monoamniotic
    • After 13th day – Conjoined twins (MC – thoracopagus)

 

Let us look at all the options:

 

  1. Monochorionic Monoamniotic: This means there is one chorionic sac and one amniotic sac. This situation is typical for monozygotic twins who split very late after fertilization( day 8-12)
  2. Monochorionic Diamniotic: This indicates one chorionic sac and two amniotic sacs. This also generally occurs in monozygotic twins, where the division happens a bit earlier than in monoamniotic twins. (day4-7)
  3. Monoamniotic Dichorionic: This combination doesn't exist in nature. Monoamniotic means one amniotic sac, and dichorionic would imply two chorionic sacs – these two conditions are mutually exclusive.
  4. Dichorionic Diamniotic (Correct Answer): This means two chorionic sacs and two amniotic sacs. This is the typical scenario for dizygotic twins, where two separate eggs are fertilized by two separate sperm. It could also occur in monozygotic twins when division occurs  before day3.

 

Educational Objective: The chorionicity and amnionicity of a pregnancy are important in understanding the type of twin or multiple pregnancy and in managing it appropriately. Dizygotic (fraternal) twins almost always result in a dichorionic diamniotic pregnancy.

 

Ref: Williams Page 865, 25th edition

questions.text: A 24-year primigravida is diagnosed to have a twin pregnancy on her first trimester ultrasound. The following image is seen on ultrasound. What is the Chorionicity of this twin?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Monochorionic diamniotic

 

  • Determination of chorionicity:
    • Determined best by ultrasound in the first trimester (8- 10 weeks)
    • Twin peak sign (Lambda sign) – Dichorionic Diamniotic Twins
    • Inverted T sign – Monochorionic Diamniotic
    • No intervening membrane in Monochorionic Monoamniotic Twins

 

 

Let us look at each option:

 

Option A. Monochorionic Diamniotic (Likely Answer): One chorionic sac but have two separate amniotic sacs. Key ultrasound features include a thin membrane separating the twins and the 'T-sign' at the point where the membrane meets the placenta.

 

Option B. Monochorionic Monoamniotic: Twins share both the chorionic and amniotic sacs. On ultrasound, there would be no membrane separating the twins. This is rarer and carries higher.

 

Option C. Dichorionic Diamniotic: This is when each twin has its own chorionic and amniotic sac. On ultrasound, this is suggested by the 'lambda (λ) sign' or 'twin peak sign,' where the placenta tissue extends between the membranes.

 

Option D. Conjoined Twins: This is a rare form of monozygotic twinning where the twins are physically connected. It's typically identifiable on ultrasound by the continuous body structure between the twins.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Lambda sign (Twin peak sign): Seen in Dichorionic Diamniotic twins on ultrasound
  • Inverted T/ Reversed T sign: Seen in Monochorionic Diamniotic twins on ultrasound

 

Ref: page no 868-869, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

questions.text:
Which of the following is correct about polycystic ovarian disease (PCOD)?

 

  1. Testosterone> 2 ng/ml

  2. Infertility

  3. High FSH/LH ratio

  4. Fasting glucose/ insulin ratio > 4.5

  5. Polycystic appearance on 1 or both ovaries on ultrasound
questions.solution:
Ans. B. b, d, e

 

  • PCOS includes chronic non ovulation, hyperandrogenism associated with normal or raised estradiol level (E2), raised LH0 & low FSH/LH ratio.

  • Diagnosis: Diagnosis is based upon the presence of any two of the following three criteria (Rotterdam Criteria)

    1. Oligomenorrhoea/or anovulation (Delayed cycles and infertility)

    2. Hyperandrogenism (Clinical &/or biochemical)

    3. Polycystic ovaries (Ultrasound finding of 1 OR both ovaries)

  • On investigations, 

    • LH: FSH ratio is increased (3:1) i.e. LH is more than FSH

    • Increase free testosterone levels

    • Increase DHEAS

    • Fasting glucose: insulin ratio < 4.5

    • Sex hormone binding globulin decreases

 

Possible late sequelae of PCOD are:

 

  • Risk of developing diabetes mellitus (15%) due to insulin resistance

  • Risk of developing endometrial carcinoma due to elevated level of estrogen.

  • Risk of hypertension & cardiovascular disease due w abnormal lipid profile (dyslipidaemia)

 

Let us look at each option

 

Option. A. Testosterone > 2 ng/ml: Elevated testosterone levels are a hallmark of PCOS, reflecting the condition's hyperandrogenic state. However, a level > 2 ng/ml is quite high and not a typical threshold for PCOS diagnosis. Elevated testosterone in PCOS is usually more modest.

 

Option. B. Infertility: Correct. Infertility is a common complication of PCOS due to chronic anovulation (lack of ovulation). Many women with PCOS struggle with infertility or subfertility.

 

Option C. High FSH/LH Ratio: This is incorrect. In PCOS, the LH to FSH ratio is often elevated (reversed), not the FSH to LH ratio. A common finding is an LH to FSH ratio greater than 2:1.

 

Option. D. Fasting Glucose/Insulin Ratio > 4.5: Correct.  While insulin resistance is a feature of PCOS, this specific ratio is not a standard diagnostic criterion for the condition. PCOS is often associated with insulin resistance, but diagnostic criteria typically don't include a specific fasting glucose/insulin ratio.

 

Option E. Polycystic Appearance on 1 or Both Ovaries on Ultrasound: Correct. One of the diagnostic criteria for PCOS, according to the Rotterdam criteria, is the presence of polycystic ovaries on ultrasound, characterized by 12 or more follicles measuring 2-9 mm in diameter, or an increased ovarian volume (>10 cm) in one or both ovaries.


Educational Objective: 

 

Polycystic ovarian disease (PCOD/PCOS) is characterized by features such as hyperandrogenism (e.g., elevated testosterone levels), infertility due to chronic anovulation, and polycystic ovaries on ultrasound. Understanding these features is key in the diagnosis and management of PCOS.

 

Ref: Page no 411, Speroffs clinical gynaecological endocrinology and infertility 9th edition

questions.text: The instrument shown below is useful in which surgery?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Myomectomy

Explanation:

  • The image is of a myoma screw. 
  • It is an instrument used in myomectomy. 
  • Myomectomy is a conservative surgery for fibroid uterus
    • It can be performed via laparotomy or laparoscopically
    • Risk of bleeding. This can be reduced
      • Preoperatively
      • GnRH agonists: They also reduce the size of the fibroid 
      • Correction of anemia/ blood transfusion
      • Uterine Artery Embolization
    • Intra-operatively
      • Use of Bonney’s uterine clamp/ uterine tourniquet (tied at the level of the uterine arteries)
      • Use of vasopressin: injected along the planned serosal incision

Educational Objective: 

 

  • The image is of a myoma screw. 
  • It is an instrument used in myomectomy. 

Ref: Page no 946, William’s Gynecology 3rd edition

choices.text: Bonnie’s clamp during surgery
Bilateral Uterine artery ligation
Ligation of vessels over the surface of the myoma
Use of vasopressin along the planned serosal incision

questions.text: A 36-year lady presents with menorrhagia. On evaluation she is found to have a large intramural fibroid. A myomectomy is planned. All are beneficial in reducing blood loss during surgery except?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Ligation of vessels over the surface of the myoma

Explanation: 

Ligation of vessels over the surface of the myoma will not help reduce blood loss significantly during  a myomectomy

Educational Objective:

  • Myomectomy is a conservative surgery for fibroid uterus
    • It can be performed via laparotomy or laparoscopically
    • Risk of bleeding. This can be reduced
  • Preoperatively
    • GnRH agonists: They also reduce the size of the fibroid 
    • Correction of anemia/ blood transfusion
    • Uterine Artery Embolization
  • Intra-operatively
    • Use of Bonney’s uterine clamp/ uterine tourniquet (tied at the level of the uterine arteries)
    • Use of vasopressin: injected along the planned serosal incision

 

Ref: Page no 946, William’s Gynecology 3rd edition

questions.text: The longest fetal diameter is?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Mentovertical diameter

 

  • Mentovertical diameter is the longest fetal diameter
  • It is seen when the presenting part is the brow

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A: Biparietal diameter is the engaging diameter (Transverse diameter) in cephalic presentation; it measures 9.5 cm
  • Option B: Suboccipitobregmatic diameter: This is the presenting diameter in a well flexed head; it measures 9.5 cm.
  • Option C: Occipito-frontal diameter: This is the presenting diameter in a deflexed head. It measures 11.5 cm

 

Educational Objective:

 

DIAMETERS OF FETAL SKULL

 

 

Ref: Page no 92 Textbook of obstetrics by JB Sharma

choices.text: Extension at hip joint, flexion at knee joint
Flexion at hip joint, extension at knee joint
Flexion at both hip and knee joint
Extension at both hip and knee joint

questions.text: A 30yr primi is diagnosed with Frank breech. Which statement is true about frank breech?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Flexion at hip joint, extension at knee joint

 

In a Frank Breech, there is flexion at the hip joint and extension at the knee joint

 

Educational Objective: 

 

 

  • Extended Breech (Frank breech): Flexion at hip joint, Extension at knee joint
  • Flexed Breech (Complete breech): Flexion at hip joint, flexion at knee joint
  • Footling breech: Extension at hip and knee joint
  • Kneeling breech: Extension at hip joint, flexion at knee joint 

 

Ref: Page no 322 JB Sharma Textbook of Obstetrics 3rd edition

questions.text: A midwife at a PHC is monitoring pregnancy and maintaining the WHO modified partograph of pregnancy progression. At how much cervical dilation should the partograph plotting be started?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 4 cm

 

Partograph

 

  • Partograph is a graphical representation of progress of labor, which is depicted using cervical dilatation and descent of head against the duration of labor.
  • It is used for early detection of abnormal labor patterns for timely intervention.
  • In a partograph the active phase of labor starts when the cervix is 4 cm dilated.
  • In active phase, cervix should dilate at the rate of 1 cm/hr.  (Alert Line)

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Partograph is a graphical representation of progress of labor, which is depicted using cervical dilatation and descent of head against the duration of labor.
  • It is used for early detection of abnormal labor patterns for timely intervention.
  • In a partograph the active phase of labor starts when the cervix is 4 cm dilated.
  • In active phase, cervix should dilate at the rate of 1 cm/hr.  (Alert Line)
  • Partograph has two lines for assessment of progression of dilation
    1. Alert line: Alert line starts at 4 cm cervical dilation & ends with full dilation of the cervix (10 cm) in 7 hours (1 cm/hour dilation rate)
    2. Action line: Action line is drawn four hours to the right of the alert line. If action line is crossed while plotting the progression, it indicates need for urgent intervention.

 

 

  • Remember that in the modified partograph, plotting starts at 4 cm onward, and the 1st mark is always put on the alert line
  • If asked, when does plotting start in the Labor care guide (Next generation partograph), then the answer is 5cm

 

Ref: Page no 212, Textbook of Obstetrics by JB Sharma 3rd edition

questions.text: Match the following fetal head diameters with their numeric values:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 1-B, 2-D, 3-C, 4-A

 

Educational Objective:

 

DIAMETERS OF FETAL SKULL

 

 

 

Fig: The Important Landmarks of fetal skull

 

Ref: Page 91, JB Sharmas Textbook of Obstetrics 3rd edition

choices.text: External podalic version
Internal podalic version

questions.text: Identify the procedure done as shown in the image
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Internal podalic version

 

  • The maneuver shown in internal podalic version
  • It is indicated in delivery of a second of twin if in transverse line and External cephalic version or external podalic version has failed.
  • It is done under GA
  • Baby is delivered by total breech extraction

 

Let us look at each option:

 

Option A. External Podalic Version: This is a procedure used to turn a fetus from a breech or transverse position into a head-down (cephalic) position by applying pressure on the mother's abdomen. It's done externally and is not indicated for the delivery of a baby.

 

Option B. Kristaller Maneuver: This is supra-pubic pressure applied in delivery of the aftercoming head in breech to maintain flexion and also in shoulder dystocia as this helps in disimpaction of the shoulder

 

Option C. Internal Podalic Version (Correct Answer): This is a procedure used primarily in the delivery of the second twin if it's in a transverse lie and external versions have failed. It involves the obstetrician inserting a hand into the uterus, grasping the fetus' feet, and delivering it by breech extraction. This is typically performed under general anesthesia.

 

Option D. Lovset Maneuver: The Lovset maneuver is a specialized technique used in the vaginal delivery of breech babies, to facilitate the safe delivery of extended arms.

 

 Educational Objective:

 

In summary, the internal podalic version is an obstetric procedure used in specific circumstances, particularly for the delivery of a second twin in a transverse position when external versions are not successful

 

Ref: page no 890, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: 24 – 28 weeks
26 – 30 weeks
28 -32 weeks
32 – 34 weeks

questions.text: Very preterm is defined as preterm birth at:
questions.solution:
Ans: C. 28- 32weeks

Educational Obective: 

Preterm is defined as period of gestation between 24w – 36w (+6d)

  • Extremely preterm is 24 – 28w
  • Very preterm is 28 – 32 w
  • Moderate preterm is 32 – 34 w
  • Late preterm is 34w – 36w (+6d)

 

 

Ref: Page no: 804, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

questions.text: A 24 y primigravida comes to the OPD. She is 5 weeks pregnant and complains of spotting PV. She is not willing for a vaginal examination. A transvaginal ultrasound reveals the following. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Threatened abortion

 

  • At 5 weeks pregnancy, a TVS should show an intrauterine gestational sac which is seen in the image hence this is a threatened abortion

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A: In a complete abortion, the uterine cavity will be empty
  • Option B: In an ectopic pregnancy, a pseudo sac or an empty intra-uterine cavity may be seen
  • Option C: In an incomplete abortion, retained products of conception will be seen

 

Educational Objective:

 

A yolk sac appears within the g. sac at 5.5 weeks

 

An embryo with cardiac activity within the g. sac at 6 weeks.

 

An Ectopic pregnancy will present on TVS as

 

  • No evidence of intrauterine pregnancy
  • Sometimes a pseudo sac is seen intra-uterine
  • Adnexal mass seen
    • G sac with or without yolk sac/ embryo
    • Heterogenous mass in the adnexa (blob sign)
    • Ring like structure in the adnexa (Bagel sign)

 

 

 

Ref: Page no. 159, William’s 25th edition

questions.text: Uterine tachysystole is a complication of induction of labor. This means the uterus is excessively contracting > …….. times in 10 minutes
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 5

 

  • Uterine tachysystole is presence of more than 5 contractions  in 10 minutes
  • Uterine hyperstimulation is Uterine tachysystole with non-reassuring fetal status

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Uterine tachysystole is presence of more than 5 contractions  in 10 minutes
  • Uterine hyperstimulation is Uterine tachysystole with non-reassuring fetal status

 

Ref: William’s textbook of Obstetrics 25th edition page480.

choices.text: Maintain continuous deflexion of head
Episiotomy should be performed as a routine
A warm cloth should be applied to the perineum to prevent trauma
Delivery should be ideally performed in a lithotomy position

questions.text: According to WHO guidelines on management of labor, which of the following is true about management of second stage of labor?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. A warm cloth should be applied to the perineum to prevent trauma

 

Let’s Discuss all the options

 

  • Option A: Maintaining deflexion of the head is not recommended. The head should be delivered by controlled extension in the 2nd stage of labor
  • Option B: Episiotomy should be restrictively used only when necessary and not routinely
  • Option C: A warm cloth should be applied to the perineum to prevent trauma. This is true. The following are recommended to prevent perineal trauma during the 2nd stage
    • Warm compress
    • Perineal massage
    • Perineal support
  • Option D: Delivery should be ideally performed in the position the patient prefers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

As per WHO recommendations of 2018,

 

As per WHO guidelines on intrapartum care for a positive birth experience (2018), these are the recommendations in 2nd stage

 

  1. Definition and duration of the second stage of labor:
    • The second stage is the period of time between full cervical dilatation and birth of the baby, during which the woman has an involuntary urge to bear down, as a result of expulsive uterine contractions.
    • In first labors, birth is usually completed within 3 hours whereas in subsequent labors, birth is usually completed within 2 hours.
  2. Recommended Birth position (for women with or without epidural analgesia)
    •  For women without epidural analgesia, encouraging the adoption of a birth position of the individual woman’s choice, including upright positions, is recommended.
  3. Method of pushing    
    •  Women in the expulsive phase of the second stage of labor should be encouraged and supported to follow their own urge to push.
  4. Method of pushing (for women with epidural analgesia)
    • For women with epidural analgesia in the second stage of labor, delaying pushing for one to two hours after full dilatation or until the woman regains the sensory urge to bear down is recommended in the context where resources are available for longer stay in second stage and perinatal hypoxia can be adequately assessed and managed.
  5. Techniques for preventing perineal trauma.
    • For women in the second stage of labor, techniques to reduce perineal trauma and facilitate spontaneous birth (including perineal massage, warm compresses and a “hands on” guarding of the perineum) are recommended, based on a woman’s preferences and available options.
  6.  Episiotomy policy
    • Routine or liberal use of episiotomy is not recommended for women undergoing spontaneous vaginal birth.
  7. Fundal pressure
    •  Application of manual fundal pressure to facilitate childbirth during the second stage of labor is not recommended.

 

In brief in 2nd stage of labor (WHO guidelines 2018)

 

Recommended

 

  • Duration of 2nd stage in primi – 3h, multi – 2h
  • Birthing position of choice
  • Encouraged to follow their own urge to push
  • Reduce perineal trauma by – hands on guarding/ warm compress/ perineal massage

 

Not recommended

 

  • Routine episiotomy
  • Fundal pressure

 

Ref: WHO recommendations: Intrapartum care for a positive childbirth experience (Feb 2018)

questions.text: Which pelvic dimension is being measured in the image shown below?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Diagonal conjugate

 

  • Diagonal conjugate is the only pelvic dimension that can be measured clinically.
  • It is as shown and is the distance between the lower edge of the pubic symphysis to the sacral promontory
  • By subtracting 1.5 cm from the diagonal conjugate, we get the obstetric conjugate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Page no 88, Textbook of Obstetrics, JB Sharma 3rd edition

choices.text: Nuchal translucency ultrasound
Chorionic villus sampling (CVS)

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman is at her second trimester prenatal visit. She inquires about screening for neural tube defects. Which prenatal screening test is used to assess the risk of neural tube defects, such as spina bifida, in the second trimester?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) screening

 

Explanation: Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) screening, typically performed in the second trimester, is used to assess the risk of neural tube defects, including spina bifida. Elevated levels of AFP in maternal blood may indicate the need for further diagnostic tests.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option B: Nuchal Translucency (NT): Done at 11-14 weeks as screening for Down syndrome. It is increased in fetuses with Down syndrome and also increased in other chromosomal abnormalities and congenital abnormalities like cardiac diseases.
  • Option C & Option D: CVS and Amniocentesis are diagnostic techniques for detecting chromosomal abnormalities.

 

Educational Objective: Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) screening, typically performed in the second trimester, is used to assess the risk of neural tube defects, including spina bifida. Elevated levels of AFP in maternal blood may indicate the need for further diagnostic tests.

 

Ref: Page no 273, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Pawlick grip
Umbilical grip

questions.text: Identify the grip in the picture used for checking ballotability of head?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Pawlick grip

 

Explanation

 

  • The image shows the #rd Leopold maneuver; also called the 1st pelvic grip; also called the Pawlik grip.

 

Educational Objective:

 

There are 4 Leopold Maneuvers:

 

  1. Fundal grip (A): to assess which fetal pole (cephalic or podalic) occupies the fundus. The breech gives the sensation of a large nodular mass; the head feel hard, round and mobile
  2. The Lateral grip (B): determines the side of the back (hard, resistant) and the limbs (numerous, small irregular mobile parts)
  3. The 1st pelvic grip (3rd maneuver aka Pawlik grip - C): determining fetal presentation.
  4. The 2nd pelvic grip (4th maneuver - D): determines the degree of descent. This maneuver is done facing the feet of the patient and trying to approximate the hands of the examiner. IF the hands approximate; the head has not descended into the pelvis. If the hands diverge, the head has descended into the pelvis.

 

 

Ref: Page 424, William’s Obstetrics; 25th edition

questions.text: A 23y woman presents to the OPD. She is worried as she is having frequent cycles of about 24 days duration. You explain to her that the normal frequency of periods is?
questions.solution:
Ans: D. 24 – 38 days

The normal frequency of menstrual cycles is 24-38 days as per the 2018 FIGO updated guidelines

Educational Objective:

  • In 2018, the FIGO updated its guidelines on definitions of normal and abnormal uterine bleeding.

 

 

Ref: https://obgyn.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/ijgo.12666

questions.text: A woman has a 6-cm adenocarcinoma of the cervix, positive para-aortic nodes found on positron emission tomography (PET) scan, and hydronephrosis. Based on these findings, which FIGO stage is she assigned?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. IIIB

 

Explanation:

  • This is stage 3B due to the finding of hydronephrosis

FIGO Staging of cervical cancer (2021)

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

  • Cervical cancer staging is a clinical staging which is aided by imaging and pathology.

 

 

 Ref: Berek and Novak 16th edition, 2455
